title: 108_s2205
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that Ukraine allows its citizens the right to emigrate with minimal taxes, complies with freedom of emigration requirements, and has made progress towards democracy and a free-market economy since 1991. Since reestablishing independence in 1991, Ukraine has made strides towards creating democratic institutions and a free-market economy. As a member of the OSCE, Ukraine is committed to developing a governance system in line with human rights principles. Despite progress in recent Parliamentary elections, there are still significant shortcomings, such as issues with election laws and public interference. Ukraine has shown progress in meeting international commitments in its recent Parliamentary elections, but significant shortcomings remain, including issues with election laws, public interference, and allegations of intimidation against opposition figures. As an OSCE member, Ukraine is committed to addressing issues related to national and religious minorities and ensuring equality for all. Legislation has been enacted to protect against incitement to violence based on identity. Ukraine has enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on identity, including anti-Semitism. It has also committed to ensuring freedom of religion and combating racial and ethnic intolerance. Ukraine is cooperating with US NGOs to combat ethnic and religious intolerance. Ukraine is continuing efforts to combat ethnic and religious intolerance by cooperating with US NGOs and restoring religious properties confiscated from minorities during the Soviet era. Ukraine has received normal trade relations treatment since a bilateral trade agreement with the US in 1992. Ukraine is progressing towards joining the World Trade Organization, addressing issues such as access for US agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, trade in services, agricultural subsidies, export incentives, and customs reform. Ukraine has enacted protections for labor rights, committed to respecting freedom of the press as an OSCE member, and established positive relations with neighboring countries. Ukraine, as an OSCE member, has committed to respecting freedom of the press. It has also established positive relations with neighboring countries and expressed a desire for European integration, democracy, and prosperity. Additionally, Ukraine has collaborated with the United States in peacekeeping operations in Europe and in the fight against international terrorism. SEC. 2. TERMINATION OF APPLICATION OF TITLE IV OF THE TRADE ACT OF 1974 TO UKRAINE. The President may determine that title IV should no longer apply to Ukraine and extend permanent normal trade relations treatment to the products of Ukraine. On the effective date of the extension, title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 shall cease to apply to Ukraine. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill its commitments as an OSCE member, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination and violence, expanding property restitution, and respecting media freedoms. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill commitments as an OSCE member, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination and violence, expanding property restitution, and respecting media freedoms. Additionally, working with Ukraine to improve in various areas, supporting efforts to protect intellectual property rights, resolving trade disputes quickly, and monitoring human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms in Ukraine. The Congress urges Ukraine to fulfill OSCE commitments, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, combating discrimination, expanding property restitution, and respecting media freedoms. Additionally, working with Ukraine to protect intellectual property rights, resolve trade disputes quickly, and monitor human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms, providing assistance to NGOs and human rights groups. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. The reports required by sections 102(b) and 203 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 shall include an assessment of specific issues. SEC. 5. CONTINUED ENJOYMENT OF RIGHTS UNDER THE JUNE 23, 1992, BILATERAL TRADE AGREEMENT. The reports under the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 must assess issues outlined in section 3(1). The trade agreement between the US and Ukraine from June 23, 1992, remains in force, granting the US rights to use safeguard rules against import surges from Ukraine under Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974. Congressional oversight over WTO accession negotiations is addressed in Section 6. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A report detailing the agreement must be transmitted to Congress within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced within 30 days of the notification, it will be considered. The 30-day period for Congress to consider a resolution of disapproval regarding the US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession begins upon the President's notification. The Congress has the authority to consider a resolution of disapproval regarding the US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession. Resolutions of disapproval can be introduced by any Member of the House and will be referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Rules. In the House of Representatives, a resolution of disapproval can be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Rules, and may not be amended by either Committee. In the Senate, a resolution of disapproval can be introduced by any Member, referred to the Committee on Finance, and may not be amended. A resolution of disapproval may be introduced by any Member of the Senate, referred to the Committee on Finance, and may not be amended. The provisions of committee discharge and floor consideration apply to a resolution of disapproval to the same extent as resolutions under the Trade Act of 1974. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate regarding resolutions of disapproval are enacted by Congress as part of their rulemaking power, superseding other rules only if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change these rules at any time.
